p.content: Pronouns come in various types, including personal pronouns, possessives, reflexives, reciprocals, demonstratives and indefinites. (Interrogative pronouns are covered in
Even though there is a concord agreement system of classifiers in
, the pronouns are not marked with classifiers.

Independent personal pronouns are words that may appear in all the positions that nouns or nominal phrases may. Some languages also have dependent forms of the personal pronouns which attach to another word in the sentence. Many languages with dependent pronouns only use the independent forms when the pronoun is emphasized or in focus.

case.caseText: does not have a separate set of dependent personal pronouns.
has dependent personal pronouns as well as the independent personal pronouns. Both sets of personal pronouns will be presented here, with the independent forms covered first.

p.content: The independent pronouns in
are marked with classifiers as part of the concord agreement system. The forms given in this section for the pronouns may be just the root, or the classifier may be shown attached.
does not have any case distinctions, so there is only a single set of pronouns that can be used in any position in the sentence, as exemplified here.
does not have any case distinctions, so there is a single set of pronouns that can be used with Agent subjects and in any other position in the sentence, as exemplified here.
The independent personal pronouns which are used for Experiencer subjects are:

caption.content: Independent Personal Pronouns for Experiencer Subjects
Independent Personal Pronouns for Expereincer Subjects

p.content: has a nominative-accusative case system, so there are distinct sets of pronouns for subjects, objects, and possessors.

case.caseText: Both Agent subjects and Experiencer subjects use the nominative pronouns, while direct objects use the accusative pronouns. There is a set of dative pronouns for indirect objects.

Agent subjects use the nominative pronouns, while Experiencer subjects use the same set of accusative pronouns that are also used for direct objects. There is a set of dative pronouns for indirect objects.
Agent subjects use the nominative pronouns, while Experiencer subjects use the dative pronouns also used for indirect objects. Direct objects use the accusative pronouns.

text.content: for Experiencer subjects or

The independent personal pronouns which are used for possessors are:
has an ergative-absolutive case system, so there are distinct sets of pronouns that can be used as subjects of transitive verbs versus subjects of intransitive verbs and objects of transitive verbs.

case.caseText: Both Agent subjects and Experiencer subjects of transitive verbs use the ergative pronouns, while both Agent and Experiencer subjects of intransitive verbs and direct objects of transitive verbs use the absolutive pronouns. There is a set of dative pronouns for indirect objects.

Agent subjects of transitive verbs use the ergative pronouns, while Experiencer subjects of transitive verbs use the same set of absolutive pronouns that are also used for subjects of intransitive verbs and direct objects. There is a set of dative pronouns for indirect objects.

Agent subjects of transitive verbs use the ergative pronouns, while Agent subjects of intransitive verbs and direct objects of transitive verbs use the absolutive pronouns. Experiencer subjects use the dative pronouns also used for indirect objects.

p.content: Possessors use the

case.caseText: ergative pronouns also.
absolutive pronouns also.
genitive pronouns, a distinct set.

case.caseText: subjects of transitive verbs are:

Agent subjects of transitive verbs are:

direct objects or for Experiencer subjects are:

p.content: Turning now to the dependent pronouns, in
the dependent pronouns attach to the verb or noun or other words as

text.content: proclitics which attach to the beginning of whatever word begins the verb phrase or nominal phrase.
enclitics which attach to the end of whatever word ends the verb phrase or nominal phrase.

either proclitics which attach to the beginning of whatever word begins the verb phrase or nominal phrase or as enclitics which attach to the end of whatever word ends the verb phrase or nominal phrase.
prefixes which attach to the verb or noun.
suffixes which attach to the verb or noun.
either prefixes of suffixes which attach to the verb or noun.
either clitics which attach to the beginning or end of the verb phrase or nominal phrase, or as affixes which attach to the verb or noun.
Some also attach ___
The dependent pronouns

case.caseText: are distinct from the classifiers.
, especially for third person, are either identical or closely related to the appropriate classifiers.

p.content: For further details about how the dependent pronouns may be used, see sections
and
where verbal agreement and missing subjects (pro-drop) are discussed.
Many languages also have possessive pronouns which can stand alone. These are distinct from those pronouns which can occur in possessor position, which were exemplified under personal pronouns above.
Many languages also have possessive pronouns which can stand alone, such as
and
in English. These are distinct from those pronouns which can occur in possessor position, such as
and
, which were exemplified under personal pronouns above.

case.caseText: does not have any possessive pronouns that stand alone as a nominal phrase.
has possessive pronouns that stand alone as a nominal phrase, as shown here:

caption.content: Stand Alone Possessive Pronouns or Phrases
Stand Alone Possessive Pronouns or Phrases

text.content: These possessive pronouns are distinct, stand alone words, not related to the other pronouns.
Some of these possessive pronouns are distinct, stand alone words, not related to the other pronouns.
These possessive pronouns are formed from another pronoun by attaching a possessive affix.
Some of these possessive pronouns are formed from another pronoun by attaching a possessive affix.

p.content: The possessive affixes are:

text.content: These possessive pronouns are formed from another word (which is not a pronoun) by attaching a possessive affix.
Some of these possessive pronouns are formed from another word (which is not a pronoun) by attaching a possessive affix.

p.content: The word that the possessive affixes attach to is:
The possessive affixes are:

text.content: These possessive pronouns are formed by using the possessor pronouns to possess a special word (which is not a pronoun) and this becomes a possessive phrase that has the same meaning and usage as a stand alone possessive pronoun.

Some of these possessive pronouns are formed by using the possessor pronouns to possess a special word (which is not a pronoun) and this becomes a possessive phrase that has the same meaning and usage as a stand alone possessive pronoun.

p.content: The special word that is possessed by the possessor pronouns is:

text.content: These possessive pronouns are formed by ___
Some of these possessive pronouns are formed by ___

p.content: Reflexives occur only in the same case as direct objects and normally must agree with the subject in person, gender, and number features.

Reflexives are another type of pronouns that most languages have. They occur only in the same case as direct objects and normally must agree with the subject in person, gender, and number features. Examples in English are:
and

. Some languages have a completely separate set of pronoun forms for reflexives, others use a phrase which consists of a noun (usually meaning ‘self’) that is possessed by the pronoun that refers back to the subject, some languages have a verbal affix which indicates reflexive action, and some languages do not distinguish reflexive constructions at all.

case.caseText: does not have any type of reflexives.
has a verbal affix to indicate reflexive action. The reflexive affix is:
has reflexives, as shown here:

text.content: These reflexive pronouns are distinct, stand alone words, not related to the other pronouns.
Some of these reflexive pronouns are distinct, stand alone words, not related to the other pronouns.
These reflexive pronouns are formed from another pronoun by attaching a reflexive affix.
Some of these reflexive pronouns are formed from another pronoun by attaching a reflexive affix.

p.content: The reflexive affixes are:

text.content: These reflexives are formed from a certain noun which is possessed by the possessor pronouns.
Some of these reflexives are formed from a certain noun which is possessed by the possessor pronouns.

p.content: The special noun that is possessed by the possessor pronouns is:

text.content: These reflexives are formed from special quantified nominal phrases.
Some of these reflexives are formed from special quantified nominal phrases.

p.content: The special quantifiers or phrases are:

text.content: These reflexives are formed by ___
Some of these reflexives are formed by ___

p.content: Some examples of reflexives in sentences, showing the reflexive affix on the verb to indicate reflexive action by the subject are:
Some examples with a reflexive used in object position of a simple sentence are:
Reciprocals are similar to reflexives except that they only occur with plural subjects.

Reciprocals are similar to reflexives except that they only occur with plural subjects. They may be formed in the same way reflexives are, or they may be distinct. For example, in English, the reciprocal forms are phrases:
and

. Some languages use only a verbal affix to indicate reciprocal action of the plural subject, others have separate pronouns, others use a possessed noun phrase or a quantified noun phrase (as in English), and some do not mark reciprocal action at all.

case.caseText: does not have any type of reciprocals.
uses a verbal affix to indicate reciprocal action.
has reciprocals, as shown here:

p.content: Some examples of reciprocals in sentences showing the reciprocal affix on the verb to indicate reciprocal action by the subject are:

text.content: These reciprocal pronouns are distinct, stand alone words, not related to the other pronouns.
Some of these reciprocal pronouns are distinct, stand alone words, not related to the other pronouns.
These reciprocal pronouns are formed from another pronoun by attaching a reciprocal affix.
Some of these reciprocal pronouns are formed from another pronoun by attaching a reciprocal affix.

p.content: The reciprocal affixes are:

text.content: These reciprocals are formed from a certian noun which is possessed by the possessor pronouns.
Some of these reciprocals are formed from a certian noun which is possessed by the possessor pronouns.

p.content: The special noun that is possessed by the possessor pronouns is:

text.content: These reciprocals are formed from special quantified nominal phrases.
Some of these reciprocals are formed from special quantified nominal phrases.

p.content: The special quantifiers or phrases are:

text.content: These reciprocals are formed by ___
Some of these reciprocals are formed by ___

p.content: Some examples of the reciprocals in sentences are:
The demonstrative pronouns specify the distance from the speaker to the item or items being referred to.

Most languages have demonstrative pronouns that are related either to the demonstratives that modify a noun or to the locative adverbs. The demonstrative pronouns specify the distance from the speaker and may have singular and plural forms. English examples are
and
, which are identical to the demonstratives which modify a noun. Demonstrative pronouns stand alone as the subject or object of a sentence, as in:
p.langData: Those are the books I asked for
p.content: and

As seen in the examples above, English only has a single set of demonstratives to use in both subject and object position. Some languages have distinct sets of demonstrative pronouns based on their case system.
In

text.content: some of

p.content: the forms of the demonstrative pronouns are

case.caseText: completely distinct from the locative adverbs.
identical to the locative adverbs, though they are used in different positions in the sentence.
identical to the locative adverbs, but others are distinct.
related to the locative adverbs. An affix is added to a demonstrative to form a locative adverb.
related to the locative adverbs. An affix is added to a locative adverb to form a demonstrative.
related to the locative adverbs in this way:

p.content: See section
for information on the locative adverbs.

text.content: The forms of the demonstrative pronouns are

case.caseText: identical to the demonstratives which modify a noun.
sometimes the same but sometimes distinct from the demonstratives which modify a noun.
distinct from the demonstratives which modify a noun.

text.content: See section
for details about the demonstratives that modifiy a noun

p.content: The demonstrative pronouns in

case.caseText: are not distinguished for case. The same forms can be used in all positions.
have separate sets for the different positions based on case.

p.content: There

case.caseText: is no distinction in the forms for referring to singular versus plural items.
are distinct forms for referring to singular versus plural items.

The demonstrative pronouns are shown in the following table, based on the distance from the speaker:
Since

has a nominative-accusative case system, there are separate sets of demonstrative pronouns for subjects and objects and possessors. The demonstrative pronouns which can be used as subjects are shown in the following table, based on the distance from the speaker:
The demonstrative pronouns which can be used as direct objects are shown in the following table, based on the distance from the speaker:
The demonstrative pronouns which can be used as possessors are shown in the following table, based on the distance from the speaker:
Since

has an ergative-absolutive case system, there are separate sets of demonstrative pronouns for subjects of transitive verbs versus subjects of intransitive verbs and direct objects of transitive verbs versus possessors. The demonstrative pronouns which can be used as subjects of transitive verbs are shown in the following table, based on the distance from the speaker:
The demonstrative pronouns which can be used as subjects of intransitive verbs or as direct objects of transitive verbs are shown in the following table, based on the distance from the speaker:
The demonstrative pronouns which can be used as possessors are shown in the following table, based on the distance from the speaker:
Since

has a split case system, there are separate sets of demonstrative pronouns for the normal nominative-accusative case system, to distinguish subjects and objects and possessors, plus others for the special cases when the ergative-absolutive case system is used, to distinguish subjects of transitive verbs versus subjects of intransitive verbs and objects of transitive verbs.
The demonstrative pronouns which can be used as subjects in the normal nominative-accusative system are shown in the following table, based on the distance from the speaker:

p.content: A final type of pronouns is indefinites. There are two basic sets of indefinite pronouns, though not all languages merge them into a single word: those consisting of a quantifier and an indefinite generic noun, such as
, and those built from an interrogative word, such as
and

Indefinites are used to refer to a nonspecific person, place or thing. They normally consist of either a quantifier and a generic noun or an interrogative word and an indefinite word, and they may not be merged into a single word.
Beginning with the first type which includes a quantifier and a generic noun (or the impersonal use of the number ‘one’), in

text.content: the indefinites are not expressed using a quantifier.
these are expressed by ___
these are expressed by a quantifier and a generic noun merged into a single word. Examples are:

Pronouns of all types normally stand alone in the place of an entire nominal phrase, but they can also be modified by a relative clause. In some languages pronouns may be modified by partitive phrases, and other languages allow pronouns to also be modified by determiners and wide scope degree words. English examples of this type include:
and
. In fewer languages, pronouns can also be modified by adjectives and possessors, acting just like nouns.
Pronouns of all types normally stand alone in the place of an entire nominal phrase, but they can usually be modified by a relative clause and sometimes by other modifiers.
In

case.caseText: pronouns only appear by themselves without any modifiers when they take the place of a nominal phrase. Not even relative clauses are allowed.
pronouns normally appear by themselves without any modifiers, but relative clause modifiers are allowed.
pronouns normally appear by themselves without any modifiers, but relative clauses and partitive phrases are allowed as modifiers.
these elements can be modified by the wide scope degree words and by articles demonstratives articles and demonstratives as well as by relative clauses and partitive phrases. Some examples are:
these elements can be modified by all the same modifiers as nouns can, including adjectives and possessors. Some examples are:

Pronouns can usually also be modified by a partitive phrase (or other PP), as in:
and

for partitive phrases with quantifiers.
In addition, it is possible to have a pronoun modified by a relative clause, as in
p.langData: you who are going with us
p.content: and
Examples of pronouns modified by a relative clause in
included in full sentences are:
In most languages that use classifiers, the classifier may occur without a noun, as long as the features of the classifier or the context make the reference clear. In

case.caseText: classifiers may occur without a noun in these situations. Some examples of nominal phrases where a classifier serves without a noun are:
a noun is always required.
